item.title: Brits Get Morning Drunk in the Snow to Celebrate Grand Reopening...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
ITV NewsItâ€™s been a long, cold, lonely winter in England.So, as four months of a nationwide lockdown finally came to an end, nothing was going to stop people from enjoying a refreshing pint of beer at the crack of dawn on a Monday morningâ€”not even driving rain, freezing temperatures, and some pretty unseasonal snowfall.Pubs started serving outdoors again as part of a reopening plan that also covers indoor gym sessions, swimming pools, non-essential shops, beauty salons, and, for those who have been gagging to see some sad animals, zoos. Prime Minister Boris Johnson had urged people to â€œbehave responsiblyâ€ with their new freedoms, but didnâ€™t explicitly say they shouldnâ€™t get drunk in the snow before having breakfast.One pub in the town of Huddersfield was swamped when it opened at the stroke of midnight. â€œWe didnâ€™t even know if anyone was going to come,â€ said the pub landlord fittingly named Ian Snowball. â€œItâ€™s in Huddersfield, itâ€™s midnight, itâ€™s freezing coldâ€”but look, everyone has come.â€If you thought you were starting early todayâ€¦ ğŸ»These drinkers in Huddersfield braved the snow to enjoy a beer garden pint at midnight â„ï¸https://t.co/UASiR7bXEv pic.twitter.com/i2O79eocSRâ€” BBC Breakfast (@BBCBreakfast) April 12, 2021 One drinker commented matter-of-factly: â€œIt was snowing earlier but I was still going to come out, I just put my coat on.â€ Another, sitting in a thick jacket next to an icy-looking gin and tonic, made the fair point: â€œAfter 14 months of not going anywhere, except funerals, itâ€™s a great place.â€Sky News reported that 50 pub-goers headed to the Fox On The Hill pub in south London this morning. The most emotional was perhaps Tony Blake, 59, who gushed to the news network: â€œI am so happy that itâ€™s open again, itâ€™s unbelievable, Iâ€™m so happy.â€ Student Sasha Carrington, 19, said she planned to stay there for the entire freezing cold day, explaining: â€œWeâ€™ve got our layers on, thermals, weâ€™re going to stay outside.â€Pippa Ingram, 51, and Sue Bell, 55, celebrated a chilly seaside pint in Kent, with Ingram describing her first sip in detail. â€œAbsolutely delicious,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not gonna last long at all! That is banging.â€ Back in Huddersfield, in footage timestamped at 8.17 a.m., a woman identified only as Sandy was seen having pints with her friends, and she told Good Morning Britain: â€œItâ€™s not that cold after a while when youâ€™re sat in the sun.â€As pub gardens reopen from today, @NickDixonITV talks to some people who have enjoyed a pint since 8am this morning.They discuss how happy they are to be back in pub gardens following the lockdown.Watch GMB ğŸ‘‰ https://t.co/6iQ6ebeOEQ pic.twitter.com/W0yAai1tGDâ€” Good Morning Britain (@GMB) April 12, 2021 One pub in Coventry appears to have taken things slightly too far. Videos posted online showed more than 100 people lining the street outside the Oak Inn after it had publized its grand plans to open a massive outdoor space with heaters, marquees and blankets. The pub is now under investigation for its â€œunmanageable amounts of visitors.â€But, largely, the grand reopening has been welcomed as a major landmarkâ€”particularly following the success of the Britainâ€™s vaccine rollout, which has many hoping that there wonâ€™t be another lockdown. Nicholas Hair, landlord of the Kentish Belle in south-east London, told BBC News that there was a â€œsense of celebrationâ€ in the country, adding: â€œIâ€™m hoping this is a sort of rebirth, and that weâ€™re reopen for the foreseeable.â€As for Boris himself, government sources confirmed that the prime minister received a long-awaited haircut on Mondayâ€”but his planned trip to the pub has been cancelled out of respect for the late Prince Philip.Read more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day. item.title: The Shady Crypto Start-Up Selling 'Shares' in Celebs...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast / Photos via Getty/ReutersIn late March, a 23-year-old named Alex Masmej logged on to Twitter to learn he had been turned into a currency. On a new social networking platform called BitClout, anyone with access to Bitcoin could, in just a few steps, buy something called the â€œalexmasmejâ€ coin. A handful of people already hadâ€”there were about 24 coins in circulation. By BitCloutâ€™s metric, a piece of Alex cost about $250.This was not an entirely new experience for Masmej. Last year, after losing his job in the pandemic, heâ€™d minted his own coin called the $ALEX token, selling what amounted to shares in his life. The first $ALEX investors to help Masmej raise $20,000 would get 15 percent of his income for the next three years; at times, they could vote on his everyday decisions. In concept, the BitClout coin was similar, but with a key difference: Heâ€™d had nothing to do with it.â€œBitClout does not ask for consent,â€ Masmej told the Daily Beast. â€œ[It] is trading on your name without you knowingâ€¦ People really donâ€™t like this, and that makes sense because it seems almost illegal.â€The platform, which has become a source of anger and bemusement in the pockets of the internet that pay attention to new crypto projects, operates sort of like a monetized Twitter. BitClout lets people speculate on prominent social media figures, buying personalized tokens that theoretically rise and fall in value with the personâ€™s popularity. The combination of hype technology and celebrity proved attractive to investors, raising over $165 million from Andreessen Horowitz, the Winklevoss twins, and Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian. But the projectâ€™s critics, of which there are many, see it as a dystopian ploy to commodify human interaction, in the mode of a â€œYelp for people.â€Masmej wasnâ€™t the only one to find himself minted into money. When BitClout launched out of private beta on March 24, some 14,000 users had pre-made profiles on the platform, copied from their Twitter accounts and converted into markets for individualized coins, nearly all without approval. Elon Musk, the top-ranked token on the website, runs for about $77,000; Ariana Grande goes for just under $25,000. Donald Trump, who places slightly below Barstool Sportsâ€™ Dave Portnoy (about $17,000), trades for nearly $15,700.Masmej found the platform funny, but others were not as entertained. The crypto-focused law firm Anderson Kill sent BitClout a cease-and-desist on behalf of a product manager at the token exchange Radar Relay, calling for his likeness to be removed from the site. â€œIt is well established that a person or company cannot knowingly use â€˜anotherâ€™s name, voice, signature, photograph or likenessâ€¦for purposes of advertising or selling...without such personâ€™s prior consent,â€ the letter reads, citing the right of publicity under California Civil Code 3344. The account was removed, but users can still technically buy its coin by searching for the original username.The premise of BitClout is fairly straightforward. Traders exchange Bitcoin for the siteâ€™s native currency, BitClout, which they must spend to register an account, send messages, or post. They can also use the currency to buy â€œCreator Coins,â€ individualized tokens issued for prominent personalities. The more people buy a given Creator Coin, the more its value rises, and vice-versa. â€œItâ€™s literally tokenized clout,â€ said Brian Fakhoury, a crypto investor who has written about the platform. â€œThe more clout you have, the more your thing is worth.â€The site is set up to capitalize on the clout of its users, requiring the most well-known accounts to engage in a bit of unpaid advertising. Figures like Masmej, whose profiles were pre-made on the site, can claim their accounts and issue tokens on their own behalfâ€”but only if they buy BitClout and tweet about the platform. Very few people have done this. One source who reviewed the websiteâ€™s backend said about 80 profiles on the platform had been claimed.Should I claim my Bitclout?â€” Snoop Dogg (@SnoopDogg) April 7, 2021 Just joined #BitClout! Excited to be a part of a new platform in the crypto space. Follow me at: https://t.co/XMkeLVV5oC BC1YLiySbpLp3y6q279SQXPgLZPqQoMxKHE9ToqDFk56jE9kwbF4gXEâ€” Tiffany Ariana Trump (@TiffanyATrump) April 7, 2021 BitCloutâ€™s launch arrived on the heels of the craze over NFTs, or â€œnon-fungible tokens,â€ cryptographic units of data stored on a blockchain that can be minted in a range of formatsâ€”Jack Dorsey turned his first tweet into an NFT; Kings of Leon released an album as oneâ€”and sold off for increasingly outrageous prices. BitClout operates on a similar premise: minting tokens that market hype as a way to directly pay creators. But while NFTs are not mutually interchangeableâ€”the owner of Dorseyâ€™s tweet NFT cannot trade it for another versionâ€”BitClout is. Like a dollar, the token can be exchanged for other BitClout. Itâ€™s a fungible token.â€œThe underlying force of NFTs is the exact same thing that drives BitClout,â€ Fakhoury said. â€œBut itâ€™s the same thing at the end of the day. They're kind of worthless assets that people give value to for no underlying reason.â€Between NFTs, now BitClout, sometimes I wonder if weâ€™re living in a simulation ğŸ¤– Things will only get weirder from here .. ğŸ‘½â€” Abigail Ratchford (@AbiRatchford) April 3, 2021 When it launched, BitCloutâ€™s creator tried to remain anonymous, identifying himself only as â€œDiamondhandsâ€â€”a slang term for someone who holds onto their financial position fiercelyâ€”in the mold of Bitcoinâ€™s pseudonymous inventor, Satoshi Nakamoto. But the attempt at secrecy crumbled quickly, when industry insiders pointed to a man named Nader Al-Naji, who later confirmed his identity to the trade publication, Decrypt. (Al-Naji did not respond to the Daily Beastâ€™s request for comment).A former Google engineer from Alexandria, Virginia, Al-Naji made a splash in the crypto-world back in 2018 with a project called Basis. The idea was to create whatâ€™s called a â€œstable coinâ€â€”a token whose value is pegged to a more reliable currency, like the U.S. dollarâ€”but to establish that stability with an algorithm, rather than backing it with actual money. Al-Naji raised a record-breaking $133 million in seed funding, but the concept proved unsustainable. After the Securities and Exchange Commission got involved, Basis shut down and returned its remaining money to investors.The failure left Al-Naji with a mixed reputation: a founder who stumbled, but didnâ€™t steal. And yet the launch of BitClout, which one investor described to Decrypt as â€œfucked up,â€ has struck many as a scam. The biggest red flag, beyond the glaring consent issue, is that while users can put money into BitClout, they cannot get it out. Traders send Bitcoin to a single account run by the BitClout teamâ€”the exact ownership of which remains unknownâ€”but itâ€™s a one-way transaction. The currency does not trade on any exchanges and thereâ€™s no way to cash out on the website.Anyone looking to actually profit from their trades on BitClout has to take more surreptitious measures. Aravind Karthigeyan, a high school student and moderator of a BitClout subreddit, told The Daily Beast heâ€™s gotten around this by reselling his tokens at a discount to individual buyers on the messaging app, Telegram.For James Prestwich, a crypto engineer and founder who has been publicly critical of BitClout, this represents a clear indication that the currency is a shitcoinâ€”crypto jargon for a scam. â€œThe only way to get Bitcoin or dollars out is to find another person and to negotiate a bespoke deal with them,â€ he said. â€œSo BitClout users, once they get in, they're trapped. There's no way out.â€â€œThere is a secondary market thatâ€™s developed on Telegram. On Telegram, OTC (over-the-counter) BitClout is usually a 40 to 50 percent discount,â€ Prestwich said. â€œSo if you want to get out, youâ€™re taking a 40 percent haircut, and the only way to do it is to manually send the BitClout to someone and hope they pay you.â€Critics have also cast doubt on the platformâ€™s security. â€œThey are very opaque,â€ Masmej said, â€œItâ€™s very hard to get to the BitClout websiteâ€¦ and even then, itâ€™s really hard on the platform to know how much theyâ€™re getting in fees or what exactly to do to sign up. We have to pay Bitcoin, but we donâ€™t really know what itâ€™s for. I think a lot of communities in crypto are really pissed off.â€Most crypto projects issue users a â€œprivate keyâ€â€”often a long phrase or string of random charactersâ€”to access their accounts. Unlike a password, private keys canâ€™t be changed. The risk is that if someone else figures out a private key, the user canâ€™t make a new one to keep them out of the account. â€œIf somebody gets your private key, you literally can't do anything with your account,â€ Fakhoury said. â€œIt is just forever compromised.â€BitClout also issues private keys, but when users log in, it caches the keys in whatever browser theyâ€™re using. As a result, the keys are more vulnerable to theftâ€”if the user clicks on a scammy pfishing link and signs in, their key could be stolen. â€œThere's a big security risk in the private keys just sitting directly in your browser,â€ Fakhoury said.For Prestwich, the more jarring revelation was that BitClout also stores the keys on its own server, uploading the data after every transaction. â€œItâ€™s not just that theyâ€™re insecurely storing keys, but theyâ€™re sending them to themselves,â€ Prestwich said. â€œThey could take all of the BitClout at any time or make arbitrary purchases on your behalf. Any BitClout you have, any employee that has access to that server can take it at any time.â€Rather than launching the platform on a ready-made blockchain like the Bitcoin-rival Ethereum, which has templates for minting new tokens using its own infrastructure, BitClout chose to develop their protocol from scratch. As a result, it was not initially a blockchainâ€”where multiple servers run the same algorithm and register transactions simultaneouslyâ€”but a single block or â€œnodeâ€ operated off one server.In its white paper, BitClout claims that other users are running nodes. And the project maintains that it is open-source, meaning anyone interested could theoretically download the source code, create a node of their own, and extend the chain. But BitCloutâ€™s creator has not released the source code. â€œThere does seem to be a blockchain there,â€ Prestwich said, â€œa poorly constructed, poorly thought out blockchain. I would suspect that there are other people who have a close relationship with BitClout who are running other nodes.â€As an investor, Fakhoury was skeptical of the projectâ€™s execution, but found the concept exciting.â€œI think it's a genius idea,â€ he said. â€œBitClout just opened Pandora's box. It opens the door to now â€˜Oh, I see this YouTuber is getting popular. I know they're gonna get more popular now and I have a way to financially benefit from that.â€™â€Masmej, who has not claimed his profile because he only uses Ethereum, said his peers were less impressed. â€œI asked my friends in crypto and they were like â€˜Dude, this is a chain for boomers,â€™â€ he said. â€œThey are only on Bitcoin, this is not going to work, and they are impersonating peopleâ€™s Twitter accounts.â€™â€Prestwich agreed: â€œThis is not the cool, hot crypto-startup. This is people who are part of the establishment trying to imitate some of the hot crypto-startups in order to make money.â€Read more at The Daily Beast.Got a tip?
